description: From Middle English vapour, from Anglo-Norman vapour, Old French vapor, from Latin vapor (“steam, heat”).

nouns.description: vapor (countable and uncountable, plural vapors) (American spelling)

entries.meaning: Cloudy diffused matter such as mist, steam or fumes suspended in the air.
The gaseous state of a substance that is normally a solid or liquid.
Something insubstantial, fleeting, or transitory; unreal fancy; vain imagination; idle talk; boasting.
(dated) Any medicinal agent designed for administration in the form of inhaled vapour.
(archaic, in the plural) Hypochondria; melancholy; the blues; hysteria, or other nervous disorder.
examples: He talks me into a fit of vapours twice or thrice a week.

verbs.description: vapor (third-person singular simple present vapors, present participle vaporing, simple past and past participle vapored) (American spelling)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become vapor; to be emitted or circulated as vapor.

examples: to vapor away a heated fluid

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To use insubstantial language; to boast or bluster.
examples: He vapoured, and fretted, and fumed, and trotted up and down, and tried to make himself pleasing in Miss Hollis's big, quiet, grey eyes, and failed.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give (someone) the vapors; to depress, to bore.
examples: “I only mean,” cried she, giddily, “that he might have some place a little more pleasant to live in, for really that old moat and draw-bridge are enough to vapour him to death […].”
